metadata.sermon_title: A Rich Complexity of Indispensable Pronouns
metadata.notes: Fourth Sunday of Easter (Year B). Focuses on grammatical structures as a metaphor for theological relationships.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher avoids 'should' or 'must' as tools of shame. Even when addressing social issues (consumerism), it is framed as a diagnostic observation rather than a moralistic attack.
quotes: It is easy enough to imagine that we—each of us—is the center of the universe.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is present through the imagery of the Good Shepherd, but it is balanced by an emphasis on the listener's own agency ('we do Easters').
quotes: God—have done all these things that make my life good, safe, and joyous in the worst kinds of contexts.

adult.analysis: The sermon is structured as a linguistic and logical review. It invites the listener to 'review what we know' and 'consider these statements,' treating the congregation as thinking subjects capable of grammatical and theological analysis.
quotes: I want to take your time this morning to review what we know about pronouns.
These eight 'You' statements reflect: Intimacy... Confidence... Thanks.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher does not speak from a place of seeking approval or instilling fear. The tone is one of shared discovery rather than forced compliance.

free_child_FC.analysis: The Free Child appears in the concluding imagery of 'jumping, leaping, and praising,' and in the creative use of grammar as a homiletical device.
quotes: That is why we are like the lame man healed . . . jumping, leaping, and praising God!

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher uses a teaching style that invites the listener's Adult to process data about the text. It moves into a Nurturing Parent -> Free Child transaction only at the end to invite joy.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: None detected. The social message (grammar) matches the psychological message (relational health).
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The sermon is remarkably transparent. The only risk is the 'we' pronoun being used to pressure the listener into 'neighborliness,' but it is presented as an 'Easter power' rather than a 'Critical Parent' demand.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The preacher avoids 'ITHY' (I'm Only Trying to Help You) by empowering the 'We' of the church rather than making the congregation dependent on the preacher's expertise. There is no 'Bait & Switch' because the grace offered in the beginning (Psalm 23) is the same power used for the work at the end (Acts/1 John).

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low; the preacher points to Jesus as the one who acts, rather than taking that role himself.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Absent; even the 'authorities' in the text are analyzed objectively rather than used as a stick to beat the listeners.
preacher_roles.victim: Absent; the preacher speaks with calm authority and clarity.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is invited into the role of 'Agent' or 'Partner' (the 'We'), rather than being kept in the 'Victim' role.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon explicitly offers an escape from the 'Victim' role of disability/dependence by highlighting the 'Easter power' to act in the neighborhood.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is a model of psychologically healthy communication. By using the 'Adult' ego state to analyze 'pronouns,' the preacher bypasses the typical Parent-Child power dynamics of the pulpit. The sermon promotes autonomy by defining the 'We' as a group with agency ('doing Easters') rather than a group that simply receives. It avoids the Drama Triangle by situating the 'Rescuer' role in the 'I' of Jesus and the 'You' of God, while inviting the congregation into a healthy, collaborative 'We'. The transition from the comfort of Psalm 23 to the challenge of 1 John is handled without a 'Switch' to the Persecutor role, maintaining a consistent tone of invitation.
strengths: Strong Adult-to-Adult engagement through the grammar metaphor.
Avoidance of 'must/should' language in favor of 'indispensable mystery'.
areas_for_improvement: The 'Free Child' element could be slightly more integrated throughout, rather than just appearing at the end.
Briefly acknowledging the 'Adapted Child's' struggle with these pronouns might deepen the empathy.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue using objective frameworks (like grammar or history) to engage the listener's Adult. This prevents the sermon from sliding into a Critical Parent 'lecture' and keeps the psychological 'contract' transparent.
